## BEACONs Representation R Functions

# `gen_network_names()`

The `gen_network_names()` takes a vector of conservation area names and combines them into network names using the separator: \code{"__"}.
Conservation area names should never include the separator: \code{"__"}, however \code{"_"} is acceptable. By default all combinations of conservation area names will be created based on the \code{k} parameter. The length of the output will therefore equal  \code{choose(length(in_names), k)}. Input names are ordered in the network name based using \code{sort()}. The output vector of names can be filtered using force_in to include specific names.

## Usage
```r
gen_network_names(
  in_names, 
  k, 
  force_in = c()
)

 
```
## Arguments
- in_names: Vector of input names. Usually the names of conservation areas from the beaconsbuilder package (e.g. PB_0001) and/or user provided reserves (e.g. PA_1).
- k: Integer > 1 and <= \code{length(in_names)}. Count of names to appear in each output network name.
- force_in: Vector of names to force in to the output vector (usually a subset of in_names but could be a substring of an output name, see examples). Only network names containing one of these vectors will be included in the output.


## ğŸ“¤ Output
A vector of network names.


## Examples
### Running the examples


1. Download and unzip BEACONs R Tools 

2. Run the examples below.

```{r evaluate_targets_using_catchments, fig.width=10, fig.height=6,  message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
# Load libraries
library(sf)
library(terra)
library(dplyr)
library(here)
library(RColorBrewer)
library(tidyr)

# --------------------------------------
# SET PARAMS  --------------------
# --------------------------------------
# Set working directory
dirpath <- here(".")

setwd(dirpath)
source("./R/names.R")
source("./R/utils.R")
source("./R/spatial.R")


ca_network <- gen_network_names(c("PB_1", "PB_2", "PB_3", "PB_11"), 2)
print(ca_network)


#Set access path 
builder_tab <- utils::read.csv(file.path(dirpath, "data/builder_tbl_sample.csv"))

network_names <- gen_network_names(
  in_names = colnames(builder_tab), 
  k = 3)
print(network_names)

```
